description: Probably from French esquiver (“slink away”), from Middle French esquiver (“to escape”), from Spanish esquivar (“to avoid, reject, elude”), from esquivo (“contemptuous, loathsome”), itself from Old French eschiver, of East Germanic origin, from Gothic *𐍃𐌺𐌹𐌿𐌷𐍃 (*skiuhs, “afraid, barefaced”), from Proto-Germanic *skeuhaz (“afraid, frightened”). Cognate with English shy, eschew.

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal) Something very easy, where one can slack off without penalty.
examples: Mr Smith's history classes are a total skive.

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal) An act of avoiding lessons or work.

verbs.description: skive (third-person singular simple present skives, present participle skiving, simple past and past participle skived)

entries.meaning: (Britain, informal) To avoid one's lessons or work (chiefly at school or university); shirk.
examples: Truancies, rather bewilderingly, have risen among children on the programme; the government hopes this is because children skive more as they get older.

description: Probably from Dutch schijf (“slice”), probably influenced by shive. Ultimately from Proto-Germanic *skībǭ (“a shaving; slice”).
Cognate to English shive, German Scheibe (“slice”), Old Norse skífa (“to cut into slices, slice”).

entries.meaning: A rotating iron disk coated with oil and diamond dust used to polish the facets of a diamond.
An angled cut or bevel at the edge of something.

verbs.description: skive (third-person singular simple present skives, present participle skiving, simple past and past participle skived)

entries.meaning: To pare or shave off the rough or thick parts of.
